{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2996070,"name":"Ethan Hanlon","username":"OccultSlolem","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/8491ac/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-21T21:14:37.317Z","cooked":"

Hey all. I’ve been doing software mentoring for a little and that’s been going fairly well, but I’ve been approached by my team and asked to also mentor their electrical team, as their main electrical student is joining the drive team and also doing some volunteering with other teams. I’m fine with helping out here, but I really don’t know much about electrical theory.

I mean, in my software mentoring role I really try to emphasize that people know what they are doing, why and how they are doing it, and understand holistically what tools they’re using. With electrical, it’s a bit more difficult for me to do that since I just don’t have that much experience in this regard. I know how to do basic electrical tasks like soldering, crimping Andersons, and I could wire up a testbed if I had to, but I’d feel a little fake since I’m just telling them what to do without understanding how or why. What are the best resources/advice you guys have for newbie electrical mentors?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-21T21:14:37.317Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":67,"reads":271,"readers_count":270,"score":389.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"Ethan Hanlon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50780,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2996159,"name":"Madeleine Odom","username":"madeleineco","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madeleineco/{size}/142674_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T00:19:02.497Z","cooked":"

Team 3847 has a very expansive list of electrical resources: https://spectrum3847.org/recommendedreading/
They’re an amazing team, and I’ve found their resources to be quite helpful.

Do you want to learn / teach more about traditional electrical concepts like voltage / current / power etc? Do you already understand that stuff?

Or do you want to teach about sensors and custom circuits and stuff like that?

I recommend (in rough order of how useful they will be):
How to wire a robot (you may already have this down but still this is most important)
Everything under Hardware Basics

If you are up for a more detailed classroom like explanation this series looks appropriate. I would probably point students to something a little shorter and…“fun” but if you really want to learn this seems to have a lot of good info!

Thanks for the resources. On top of those, I was looking for more general pedagogic advice on how to be an optimal electrical mentor. If you have any tips or experiences with that that would be great.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T01:10:58.907Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"Ethan Hanlon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":18342,"username":"jdaming","name":"Jason Daming","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jdaming/{size}/137720_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50780,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996199,"name":"Mr.R^2","username":"Mr.R_2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mr.r_2/{size}/89723_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T01:27:17.508Z","cooked":"

As a non-EE, but long-time theatre technician, I like to use Neopixel strips. In my mind it is a great combination of simple and complex implementation of electrical and programming concepts (the programming is actually a bit complex with the straight WPILib implementation as it involves a buffer, but other devices can simplify that).

They have seperate power requirements for signal and running voltage, and you can easily control and measure how much power they are drawing. More leds and more bright white to your colors, more power. Also, they need really good connections to work correctly

Most importantly, they look really cool.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T01:27:17.508Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":69.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"Mr.R^2","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30291,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996204,"name":"Jim Forbes","username":"MrForbes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrforbes/{size}/165505_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T01:32:47.780Z","cooked":"

I’m an ME with a EE father, father in law, and brothers…so I got exposed to it a long time ago, and have a little understanding.

I’ve also been 1726s lead mechanical mentor for a long long time. We had an electronics mentor, not a EE, but very knowledgeable, but he retired from mentoring several years ago. I’ve taken over. Turns out, you can usually build a working FRC robot without knowing everything there is to know about how it works. It’s good to understand something about motor behavior, battery behavior, how to make good electrical connections with low resistance, how to trouble shoot system problems, how to make some custom circuits or at least enough to oversee what the students are doing as they figure them out, and help them get them on the robot so they have a chance of working.

I try not to get too deep into the theory of anything on the robot, unless asked about it…I tried that when I first started, and decided it was better left as a reason for the students to further their education.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T01:33:58.202Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":136,"readers_count":135,"score":142.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"Jim Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50780,"username":"OccultSlolem","name":"Ethan Hanlon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/8491ac/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/7","custom_user_title":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996246,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T03:56:19.562Z","cooked":"
MrForbes:

Turns out, you can usually build a working FRC robot without knowing everything there is to know about how it works. It’s good to understand something about motor behavior, battery behavior, how to make good electrical connections with low resistance, how to trouble shoot system problems, how to make some custom circuits or at least enough to oversee what the students are doing as they figure them out, and help them get them on the robot so they have a chance of working.

I try not to get too deep into the theory of anything on the robot, unless asked about it…I tried that when I first started, and decided it was better left as a reason for the students to further their education.

As a practicing EE, I concur. I have noticed that a lot of people have have a relatively easy time visualizing and understanding mechanical systems and machines. I have also noticed that many people have trouble visualizing electrons racing around in conductors since one cannot “see them with one’s eyes”. Those people often have no trouble understanding the higher level function of some electrical component or piece of equipment.

Taking a more practical approach and teaching them how to do electrical construction will be more productive. By this, I mean teaching thigs such as how to run wires, how to do crimping properly, how to choose the proper size wires from a table/chart based on data from the load.

Making everyone understand the fundamentals of electricity before allowing them to build robots is like making them understand the gory details of metallurgy or how to do a proper, rigorous stress analysis before they are allowed to design a robot structure. Allowing them to “wing it” and rely on their intuition (and possibly failing) is what inspires the students to go study these fields later in life, at least in my case.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T03:58:36.698Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":35.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996263,"name":"josesantos","username":"josesantos","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/josesantos/{size}/5743_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T05:15:06.276Z","cooked":"
philso:

As a practicing EE, I concur. I have noticed that a lot of people have have a relatively easy time visualizing and understanding mechanical systems and machines. I have also noticed that many people have trouble visualizing electrons racing around in conductors since one cannot “see them with one’s eyes”. Those people often have no trouble understanding the higher level function of some electrical component or piece of equipment.

I would start with a practical goal and try to determine the right framework or teaching style for your community to reach that goal. For example, you might say:

  • All members of the Electrical Sub-team should be able to identify the major control system components and wire up a control system to power and control the Kit of Parts drivetrain.

The above goal assumes limiting the scope of Electrical work in FRC to plumbing together all the black boxes in the legal control system to achieve basic functionality. Having been an Electrical Sub-team deputy lead, then a team captain, I think the above is a reasonable goal for most teams. If your team is small, this “Sub-team” may just be one or two people.

One step above this could be:

  • Advanced members of the Electrical Sub-team should be able to wire up any of the sensors available from an FRC-specific vendor (AndyMark, CTRE, REV, etc.) to the FRC control system.

Another step above this could be:

  • Advanced members of the Electrical Sub-team should be able to identify functional alternatives to any sensors available from FRC-specific vendors, and determine how to wire up those sensors to the FRC control system. (e.g: wiring up an encoder or potentiometer from Digikey or Amazon to the RoboRIO or directly to a motor controller).
","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T05:15:06.276Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"josesantos","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50780,"username":"OccultSlolem","name":"Ethan Hanlon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/8491ac/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17071,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996264,"name":"josesantos","username":"josesantos","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/josesantos/{size}/5743_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T05:23:57.437Z","cooked":"
josesantos:

Advanced members of the Electrical Sub-team should be able to identify functional alternatives to any sensors available from FRC-specific vendors, and determine how to wire up those sensors to the FRC control system. (e.g: wiring up an encoder or potentiometer from Digikey or Amazon to the RoboRIO or directly to a motor controller).

A very practical goal along these lines could be:

  • Advanced members should be able to create a test bench for running motors on prototypes using mostly FRC-legal control system components but without a RoboRIO to generate PWM for the motor controllers.

For the above goal, you might imagine a test bench where the RoboRIO is replaced by a $15 Arduino from Amazon or a similarly cheap RC Servo PWM generator. I want to say nowadays the fancy new Spark Max can be controlled with a PC using the USB C port. In any case, this practical exercise can give students more insight into what some of these blackboxes are doing.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T08:26:42.286Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":79,"readers_count":78,"score":65.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"josesantos","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/KEYESTUDIO-Leonardo-Development-Board-Arduino/dp/B0786LJQ8K/ref=sr_1_2?crid=1PBVOQPSC6W3Y&keywords=arduino+leonardo&qid=1642839916&sprefix=arduino+leonardo%2Caps%2C115&sr=8-2","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/Globact-Digital-Consistency-Helicopter-Airplane/dp/B08DM2CP3T/ref=sr_1_6?crid=249T1ILGVTXZR&keywords=servo+tester&qid=1642839981&sprefix=servo+tester%2Caps%2C116&sr=8-6","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17071,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996298,"name":"Ken Pontbriant","username":"electroken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/electroken/{size}/160387_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T11:53:42.500Z","cooked":"

Over the last decade I’ve had only a few students express interest about what’s going on in all the little black boxes. We do spend a lot of time on proper connections and signal integrity. I’m always happy to get a student who wants to practice crimping JST contacts until they are done perfectly. Our best electrical systems are the ones we can forget about for the duration of the competition season.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-22T11:53:42.500Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":44.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400985,"topic_slug":"dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring","display_username":"Ken Pontbriant","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17612,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 230 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/dummy-approaching-electrical-mentoring/400985/11","custom_user_title":"FRC 230 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2996300,"name":null,"username":"veg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/3be4f8/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-22T11:57:16.888Z","cooked":"
philso:

Taking a more practical approach and teaching them how to do electrical construction will be more productive. By this, I mean teaching thigs such as how to run wires, how to do crimping properly, how to choose the proper size wires from a table/chart based on data from the load.

^^^ THIS.

The most important things to understand are where the wires go, what size (gauge) wire and fuses to use on each circuit, and how to make good, reliable electrical connections. The Zero To Robot tutorial has a lot of the reference materials you need.

Study the “how to” wiring diagrams, and post a printout on the wall of your shop. Learn how to crimp wires and do a proper tug test.

If you can diagnose software bugs, you can diagnose electrical problems.

You’ll be fine.
